title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text: üîóSource Code (Git) ¬†¬† üîóDemo Video

title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text:
Overview
The Face Detect Follow Robot is an autonomous human-tracking system that recognizes, identifies, and physically follows a specific user in real time. Unlike simple motion-following robots, this project focuses on identity-aware tracking, meaning the robot only follows a registered person instead of anyone appearing in front of the camera. This capability is achieved through a hybrid perception system combining classical computer vision, deep-learning detection, head-pose analysis, and embedded robot control.
The robot begins by registering the target user‚Äôs face using Haar Cascade detection. Thirty aligned face images are collected for identity matching. During operation, the system continuously detects faces, extracts features, compares them with the registered target, and only activates ‚Äúfollow mode‚Äù after multiple consecutive matches ensure stable identification.
To handle natural human movement‚Äîsuch as turning the head, rotating the face, or temporarily looking away‚Äîthe system integrates head pose estimation, adjusting follow direction based on the nose‚Äôs relative position. When the target‚Äôs face becomes occluded or leaves the camera view, the robot switches to YOLOv8 full-body tracking, maintaining pursuit until the face reappears. This multimodal pipeline ensures reliable tracking even in difficult visual conditions.
Movement decisions are derived from the target‚Äôs horizontal offset from the frame center and the apparent face size relative to distance. Commands are transmitted to an Arduino-controlled robot via serial communication, enabling smooth forward, backward, and lateral motion.
Overall, this project demonstrates how classical vision, deep-learning detection, and embedded control can be combined to produce a natural, adaptive, human-aware robotic behavior suitable for personal assistance, education, and security applications.

title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text:
System Description
The robot‚Äôs perception pipeline integrates:

Face registration using Haar Cascade detection

Face alignment via eye position normalization

Identity verification using distance-based comparison

Head pose estimation via nose deviation

YOLOv8 person detection as fallback when face is not visible

Serial communication to coordinate real-time robot motion

Tracking stability is enhanced through:

Consecutive match filtering

Adaptive thresholds for follow/search states

Dynamic YOLO fallback

Center-tolerance alignment margins

title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text:
Technical Architecture

Computer Vision

Haar Cascade face/eye/nose detection

Eye-based rotational alignment

Nose offset for yaw estimation

Distance-based face comparison for ID verification



Deep Learning

YOLOv8 (Ultralytics) for person detection

Runs every N frames for efficiency

Confidence-based switching between modes



Robotics Integration

Arduino motor controller

Real-time command transmission (PySerial)

Commands: forward, backward, turn left/right, diagonals, stop

Adaptive control based on face size & position

title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text:
Applications

Personal assistant robots that follow owners around the home

Security robots that identify and track approved individuals

Educational robotics for teaching computer vision pipelines

Interactive robot prototypes for HRI (Human‚ÄìRobot Interaction) research

title: Human-Following Robot with Real-Time Face Tracking
text:
Conclusion
The Face Detect Follow Robot demonstrates a practical fusion of classical CV algorithms, deep-learning detection models, and embedded robot communication to achieve identity-specific human tracking. Through multimodal perception‚Äîface alignment, head pose estimation, YOLO fallback detection‚Äîthe robot maintains stable pursuit across varied visual conditions and natural human behavior.
This project highlights the importance of combining interpretability, robustness, and real-time performance in human-centered robotics. While already highly functional, future improvements such as FaceNet embedding-based recognition, ROS navigation, obstacle avoidance, or voice-command integration would further expand its capabilities into a fully autonomous, socially aware robotic system.

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text: üîóSource Code (Git) ¬†¬† üîóFinal Report (PDF) ¬†¬† üîóFinal Presentation (PDF)

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text:
Three-Stage NLP Pipeline

1. Justice-Based Ethics Classifier

DistilBERT fine-tuned on ETHICS dataset (Hendrycks)
Trained on commonsense / justice / combined subsets
Detects fairness violations and moral inconsistencies
Evaluated distribution shifts across 6 model variants



2. Hate Speech & Toxicity Classifier

3-class HateXplain classifier (hate, offensive, normal)
Generates probability vectors for each sentence
Combined toxicity metric: p_hate + p_offensive



3. UNESCO Ethics Principle Mapper

Sentence-transformer embeddings
Cosine similarity mapping to 11 UNESCO AI Ethics principles
Produces interpretable ethical-dimension labels

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text:
Techniques

Label smoothing (0.1)
Dropout (0.2) + attention dropout (0.2)
Weight decay
Reduced epochs (3 ‚Üí 1)
Metrics: F1 score, calibration, confusion matrix

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text:
Model Variants

full_v1 / full_v2

commonsense_v1 / commonsense_v2

justice_v1 / justice_v2

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text:
4 Final Risk Categories

both ‚Äî justice + hate/offensive

justice_only ‚Äî fairness violations only

hate_only ‚Äî toxicity-only

none ‚Äî no detected violations

title: Measuring Ethical Risks in AI-Generated News Using NLP
text:
Metrics

Average unethical probability
Violation ratios (unethical_ratio, hate_offensive_ratio)
UNESCO principle dominance
KDE distributions & visualization

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text: üîóSource Code (Git) ¬†¬† üîóReport PDF

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Overview
This project investigates the question: ‚ÄúHow does the use of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) contribute to the improvement of education for children in underprivileged countries between 2017 and 2023?‚Äù
The study uses multidimensional datasets from UNESCO, ITU, and SDG4, conducting cross-country and time-series analyses. It explores how ICT accessibility, digital literacy skills, and infrastructural readiness influence learning outcomes. The research identifies meaningful relationships between ICT development and improvements in reading proficiency, math skills, school completion rates, and digital competencies.

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Research Purpose
The digital divide remains a major obstacle for educational development in underprivileged regions. This study examines whether ICT serves as a mechanism to reduce disparities and strengthen learning outcomes. The project analyzes macro-level indicators, such as internet access, digital literacy rates, and basic educational achievements, focusing on long-term trends from 2017 to 2023.

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Target Regions

Sub-Saharan Africa
Central and Southern Asia
Eastern and South-Eastern Asia
Latin America and the Caribbean

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Research Methodology

Data Sources

UNESCO Education Statistics
ITU ICT Indicators
World Bank SDG4 Global Database



Tools and Techniques

Python (pandas, numpy, matplotlib, seaborn)
Time-series visualization
Cross-regional comparison
Correlation and trend analysis

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Variables

Dependent Variables (Educational Outcomes)

Reading proficiency (Grade 2/3, primary, lower secondary)
Mathematics proficiency
Primary and upper-secondary completion rates
Educational attainment levels
Digital literacy indicators by age



Independent Variables (ICT Access and Infrastructure)

Broadband availability
Barriers to internet use
ICT skill levels
Internet usage in educational environments

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Data Analysis Summary

Educational Outcomes

Sub-Saharan Africa displays the largest performance gap.
Certain countries show steady improvement, though at different magnitudes.
For example, Benin‚Äôs Grade 2 reading proficiency increased from 9.6 percent to 37.7 percent between 2014 and 2019.



ICT Skills and Digital Literacy

Significant disparities exist among regions.
Youth aged 15‚Äì24 consistently show stronger digital skills than children under 15.
Basic digital competencies remain limited in many low-income countries.



Correlation Findings

Higher ICT accessibility correlates positively with improved learning outcomes.
However, causation cannot be confirmed due to data limitations.
Incomplete or inconsistent reporting reduces statistical robustness in some analyses.

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Policy Implications

Long-term investment in ICT infrastructure is essential for sustainable educational development.
Device distribution alone is not sufficient; structured digital literacy training is required.
Region-specific policy approaches are necessary, considering socioeconomic and infrastructural differences.
Improvements in national data reporting systems are needed to support more reliable analysis.

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:
Conclusion
The project finds strong evidence that ICT positively influences educational outcomes in underprivileged countries. Enhanced digital literacy, improved internet access, and broader ICT availability correlate with higher reading and math proficiency as well as greater school completion rates. The results emphasize the importance of ICT as a transformative tool for educational equity, while also highlighting the need for targeted strategies, infrastructure investment, and better monitoring systems.

title: ICT Education Impact Analysis (2017‚Äì2023)
text:

git clone https://github.com/annakim9237/ict-education-impact-2017-2023.git
cd ict-education-impact-2017-2023

pip install pandas numpy matplotlib seaborn openpyxl xlrd jupyter

jupyter notebook ict-for-underprivileged-education.ipynb

It contributes to academic and policy discussions by presenting a multi-year, cross-regional quantitative evaluation based on internationally recognized indicators.

title: Oil Fraud Crime Pattern Analysis
text:
Overview
This project investigates nationwide fuel station fraud patterns by integrating regulatory data, business information, and geospatial risk factors. In collaboration with the Korea National Oil Management Institute, the analysis explores behavioral trends, environmental features, and historical violations to build predictive insights for fraud detection.

title: Oil Fraud Crime Pattern Analysis
text:
What I Did

Collaborated with the Korea National Oil Management Institute to analyze nationwide fuel station violation data and business registration information.
Collected and integrated external datasets such as proximity to police stations, streetlight density, and local station clustering to enhance risk modeling.
Applied machine learning models (Random Forest, Decision Tree) to identify high-risk fuel stations and evaluate fraud likelihood.
Used QGIS and geospatial visualization techniques to map risk hotspots and illustrate key environmental factors.
Summarized insights for regulatory teams through PowerPoint, supporting targeted and data-driven inspection planning.

Built predictive models capable of ranking stations by risk level to support proactive regulatory intervention.
Visualized spatial fraud patterns revealing geographic clusters and recurring behavioral indicators.

Overview
This project evaluates the economic impact of COVID-19 at the U.S. state level by integrating multiple datasets spanning health data, housing markets, labor statistics, GDP, income, and household debt. Using R and tidyverse tools, the analysis compares pre-pandemic (2017‚Äì2019) and post-pandemic (2020‚Äì2022) trends to reveal structural economic shifts.

text:

Performed extensive data cleaning and cross-timeframe alignment to enable fair comparisons between pre-COVID and post-COVID economic conditions.
Created bar plots, line graphs, and violin plots to visualize changes in spending, debt, income, and unemployment across 50 states.
Delivered an interactive HTML report summarizing economic trends and identifying states with stronger or weaker resilience during the pandemic.

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text: üîóSource Code (Git) ¬†¬† üîóDemo Video

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Overview
Ensuring safe and habitable housing is an essential component of urban governance‚Äîespecially in densely populated cities like Toronto, where aging infrastructure and socioeconomic disparities directly influence building quality. RentSafeTO is the city‚Äôs primary regulatory program for assessing rental apartment safety, covering a wide range of compliance categories including structural integrity, fire protection, pest management, waste disposal, lighting, ventilation, and general maintenance.
However, the official inspection process is slow, reactive, and resource-intensive. Most renters and landlords must wait months before receiving inspection outcomes, and inspectors cannot feasibly assess thousands of properties at once. This creates a need for proactive, data-driven models that estimate building safety risk before formal inspections occur, allowing informed decision-making for renters, landlords, and municipal agents.
This project develops a comprehensive machine learning pipeline analyzing 11,760 Toronto apartment buildings across 40 structural, historical, and environmental features provided through Toronto Open Data. The system predicts RentSafeTO safety outcomes‚Äîpass vs fail or high-risk vs compliant‚Äîusing classical machine learning models paired with targeted feature engineering and imbalance mitigation strategies.
The pipeline explores both regression and classification paradigms, using models such as Linear Regression, Random Forest Regression, Decision Trees with SMOTE, and K-Nearest Neighbors. Although regression models show extremely high goodness-of-fit (R¬≤ up to 0.98), they fail to capture the unique structure of RentSafeTO scoring‚Äîwhere perfect evaluations map to 100 points regardless of underlying weighted components. Instead, the SMOTE-enhanced decision tree classification approach provides a more interpretable, reliable, and balanced predictive framework, especially given the severe class imbalance in safety failures.
Ultimately, this project demonstrates how regulatory datasets‚Äîoften noisy, biased, and imbalanced‚Äîcan be transformed into actionable safety insights that support tenants, policymakers, and property managers. It illustrates the practical challenges of urban analytics while showing how machine learning can augment existing inspection systems to improve equity, efficiency, and public well-being.

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Problem Context

RentSafeTO evaluates buildings across safety standards: fire systems, structural integrity, pests, maintenance, waste control, air circulation, security systems.
Inspection schedules are slow and reactive.
Predictive modeling supports:

Tenants choosing safe housing

Landlords identifying weak points

Municipal governments prioritizing high-risk buildings


Dataset: 11,760 apartment buildings √ó 40 structural/geographic/compliance features

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Data Analysis

Conducted exploratory analysis on Toronto Open Data

Addressed severe class imbalance (most buildings scored 100)

Cleaned temporal inconsistencies from evolving dataset

Analyzed:

Structural attributes (age, height, floors)
Geographic factors (wards, neighbourhoods)
Historical compliance scores
Audit frequency
Violations across categories (fire, structural, pest, waste, cleaning)

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Feature Engineering
Created predictive features from:

Building structure ‚Äî floors, height, age

Geography ‚Äî ward, location clusters

Management attributes ‚Äî property type, ownership model

Historical evaluation ‚Äî past scores, frequency of audits

Violation categories ‚Äî pest, fire, waste, structural, cleanliness

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Model Development

Regression Models

Linear Regression:

R¬≤ = 0.98, RMSE = 10.01

High fit but errors spike for rare failing buildings

Random Forest Regression:

R¬≤ = 0.96, RMSE = 2.04

More stable with nonlinear feature interactions




Classification Models

Decision Tree + SMOTE:

Accuracy = 82.6%

Best performance for rare failure cases

Synthetic minority oversampling improved balance

KNN Classifier:

Mean CV score = 0.67

Limited performance but consistent variance

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Model Selection Rationale

Regression unsuitable because RentSafeTO uses binary perfect scores ‚Üí results collapse toward 100.
Minority class (failures) extremely underrepresented.
Classification isolates failure vs compliant buildings more effectively.
SMOTE addresses the dataset‚Äôs structural limitations.
Decision Trees offer transparent rule-based interpretation for regulators and property owners.

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Technical Implementation

Python, Pandas, scikit-learn, imbalanced-learn
SMOTE oversampling for minority disqualification records

Cross-validation for robust error estimation

Separated notebooks for EDA, feature engineering, training, evaluation

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Business Impact

Enables preliminary safety risk assessment without waiting for inspectors

Helps renters identify unsafe apartments before signing leases

Guides proactive maintenance strategies for building owners

Improves city-wide inspection efficiency and resource allocation

Establishes foundation for real-time housing risk monitoring

title: Toronto Building Audit Risk Analysis & Prediction
text:
Conclusion
This project demonstrates how machine learning can support regulatory systems by predicting building-level safety risks in a clear, interpretable, and operationally useful manner. Despite the inherent challenges of highly imbalanced datasets and the rigid scoring structure of RentSafeTO, the SMOTE-enhanced decision tree achieves balanced, realistic performance that aligns with real-world use cases. The model provides transparent, rule-based insights into why a building might be at risk‚Äîmaking it more useful to tenants, landlords, and policymakers than purely numerical regression models.
The results reveal important structural patterns in Toronto‚Äôs rental market: older buildings, tall complexes, and properties with repeated historical violations show higher risk. Meanwhile, geographic disparities suggest that socioeconomic factors at the ward level may influence building maintenance quality and inspection frequency.
More broadly, this project illustrates that urban safety analytics requires both technical rigor and social awareness. Machine learning alone cannot solve regulatory gaps, but it can dramatically enhance visibility into housing conditions, making data-driven governance more efficient and equitable. Future improvements‚Äîsuch as collecting more failure cases, integrating geospatial features, or applying gradient boosting methods‚Äîwould further strengthen predictive performance and support fairer housing outcomes across Toronto.

Applied partition-based parallelism and caching optimization

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text: üîóSource Code (Git) ¬†¬† üîóFinal Report (PDF)

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text:
Overview
This project focuses on building a scalable and distributed data pipeline for analyzing large volumes of NYC taxi trip data. Using PySpark and AWS services, the system processes millions of records, integrates multiple storage layers, and evaluates modern analytical engines to optimize performance and latency.

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text:
What I Did

Built a distributed data pipeline using PySpark and AWS EC2/S3 to process millions of NYC taxi trip records.
Integrated AWS Glue and Athena to enable high-performance schema management, data cataloging, and federated querying.
Benchmarked analytical engines such as DuckDB and Polars to identify performance gaps and optimize computation speed.
Developed reproducible large-scale workflows to improve query efficiency across different storage formats and processing frameworks.

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text:
Methods & Tools
PySpark ¬∑ AWS EC2 ¬∑ AWS S3 ¬∑ AWS Glue ¬∑ AWS Athena ¬∑ DuckDB ¬∑ Polars ¬∑ Python ¬∑ Distributed Computing

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text:
Key Results

Achieved substantial reductions in pipeline latency by comparing analytical engines and optimizing execution plans.
Enabled scalable querying and transformation of large datasets through AWS Glue/Athena integration.
Demonstrated effective multi-engine benchmarking for real-world big-data decision making.

title: Distributed Big Data Processing of NYC Taxi Trips
text:
Impact
This project showcases expertise in distributed data engineering, workflow optimization, and cloud-based analytics‚Äîcore skills for large-scale ML and data engineering roles.
